content:
It may help to post screenshot of the error message as it displayed, also showing the screen where it occurred. I found a few links of possible use. Keep us posted.

The correct incoming server is imap.comcast.net for IMAP or pop3.comcast.net for POP, plus you have to enable access to the account by mail apps like TB: Set Port to 587 Set Connection Security to : STARTTLS for SMTP smtp.comcast.net, normal password 

https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/third-party-email-access https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/email-client-programs-with-xfinity-email
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you so much David, this really helped! So now I have the comcast email with all folders in Thunderbird and my goal is next to add gmail to Thunderbird and then merge the comcast into the gmail. The goal is to have all the old comcast emails and folders integrated into gmail so the comcast can be cancelled as Xfinity phases out the comcast email. Does that sound doable to you? Not sure how to do it. Thanks again!
creator: jafischer6

content: Yes, its doable, but go slowly. Once you have the gmail account setup, you can COPY (not move) the messages from comcast account to gmail account. Since you will be copying messages from one server to another, there can be interruptions in the network, so I suggest copying in small groups. There is no one perfect approach; you could attempt to copy a complete folder and that may go smoothly.

content: Download the Thunderbird installer from https://www.thunderbird.net/ Run the installer and select 'Custom' Setup Type. The Setup Wizard will prompt you to 'Choose Install Location'.
creator: christ1

content: The Unified Folders feature shows those folders that are in different accounts yet have the same name. They are root folders, not subfolders. Inbox, sent, draft, trash are the norm. There is always the possibility that a folder is not being represented. To correct that, rightclick on the unified folder, then click choose to ensure that all related folders are shown.
creator: davidsk

content: Is this Gmail? If so, please remember that AllMail is, indeed, All Mail. and that includes the trash folder. The general recommendation is to unsubscribe from allmail folder. that cuts disk usage in half, cuts transmission time in half, and reduces computer resources noticably.

content: Check the setting found at <Tools | Settings | Privacy & Security | Mail Content | Allow remote content in messages>. If enabled, you will see images that are linked to your message displayed without further action from you. Keep in mind that this can be dangerous, or at least a security lapse - automatically displayed images can alert the sender that you have opened the email, which you may not want, especially in the case of spammers and scammers. Better to leave the setting turned off and enable it only for sources you trust.
creator: rednoise

content:
You can't disable the setting, but you can attach files from the received message to the reply by drag and drop.

Or, try this add-on:

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/reply-with-attachments/
creator: sfhowes

content: Thunderbird is not the only e-mail client that does not include received attachments in replies. I've long had the habit of forwarding messages instead of replying when I wanted to keep the attachments in my reply.
